Thank you all for the suggestions.  I'm just getting back on this 
now aft=
er being pulled to higher priority things.  What could be 
higher priority =
than unit tests!?

I've checked out the Parameterized test runner.  Nice ad=
dition and I 
can make it work this way.  However, one thing I'm not happy =
with is 
that it is the 'cross product' of the Test methods and parameters.=
  
Thus I can't have a bunch of test methods for a single parameterized 
in=
stance.  It's sortof missing the 'before'/'after' hooks needed to 
set it u=
p the way I'd like -  Configure, Test A, Test B,..., 
Shutdown.  The 'Befor=
eClass'/'AfterClass' hooks don't work either as 
they are only called once =
in total.

I sortof expected it to instantiate the class and then run all t=
he 
test methods (seeing how it was on the constructor).  But it doesn't 
w=
ork this way.

Craig




--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "hurne_jim" <hurne_j=
im@...> wrote:
>
> 
> JUnit 4 actually has a Parameterized custom test runn=
er that allows
> you to run the same test(s) with different parameters.  Ta=
ke a 
look at
> org.junit.runners.Parameterized in the JUnit Javadoc.
> 
> =
I've been working on an "XML" version of Parameterized that allows 
you
> t=
o store your test parameters in an XML file.  It's part of the
> JunitExt p=
roject (http://www.junitext.org).  I must warn you that 
it's
> still in th=
e early stages of development.
> 
> However, it sounds like using Parameter=
ized might be easier than my
> XMLParameterizedRunner, as you'll likely nee=
d to do something
> programatically with Hibernate.
> 
> The nice thing abo=
ut custom test runners is that they work with 
IDEs.
>  For example, you ca=
n use Parameterized and still be able to run 
the
> tests from within Eclip=
se.
> 
> -Jim Hurne
